p.s: To really understand HelensHelen's situation you have to look very deep into the excerpt from the novel Gun Love, by Jennifer Clement, published in 2019, which deals with 14-year-old Pearl and her situation living in a car with her mother and her situation after her mother gets shot.
In her new foster home Pearl meets two other children, Leo and Helen.
Helen is eight years old but look[s] about five (l. 3).
She smells like burned marshmallows, which reminds Pearl of her past, burning marshmallows in her car with a lighter (ll. 3,4).
Helen is also very talkative and has no idea who she is or where she comes from (ll. 5,6).
You can see that when she tells Pearl about her different mothers with different ethnics, her ten brothers, eleven sisters, her twin brother and two twin sisters.
She is also from Ethiopia and from Finland.
She was told she was born in a house, but another foster home told her she was born in a hospital (ll. 6-9).
Helen is described as a true-blue foster child (l. 11), because she has had many different homes and families, still remembers every little detail about them and sees them as her real family.
She also does not even try to figure out her real past, because she really believes these people are her family.
All these families gave her a phone and charger to keep in touch with her.
And eventhougheven though she does not know which phone belongs to which family she kept all of them to call her family and friends, which shows that she is very loyal.
Helen is not complicated rather a simple human being.
She dreams of snow on Christmas in Florida, she loves forehead kisses and she tells Pearl, that she feels better after a shower (ll. 18-20).
Everything she is talking about is out of order there is no way to follow her and attempt to make sense of her life (l. 22f.).
The different homes, many changes and not knowing the truth affected her in a way that her thoughts are hona mixed up and twisted in her head.
Helen has a twisting nature.
Shortly after meeting Pearl she is already sitting close besides her and rubb[ing] her forehead against [Pearl's] upper arm (l. 41, 42).
Helen is speaking about herself in third person, which highlights her identification issues.
Her thoughts are expressed very simple in a few words for example Helen loves forehead kisses (l. 19).
This is proof for PearlsPearl's thesis, that nobody had thaughttaught her things (l. 12) and nobody is correcting her (l. 17).
Normal eight year olds do not really think about simple things like this and they also do not talk in third person about themselves.
Helen does not know anything about her real mother and her real father but she also does not question it because her foster families told so many different stories and she is believing them all.

She also talks about three friends, who she wants to call, which means that their numbers are somewhere in her 17 different phones and it will probably take very long to find them, which again shows Helen's messy life.

All in all Helen is a simple but gullible person and has a loving and affectionate personality shown through her knowledge about all her past foster homes, even though she has not had contact with them in years.
